items.message:
River levels are now falling on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook but are due to rise again this evening due to more rainfall. 

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the road at Reybridge. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area and we will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/01/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high at the Brinksway river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around Micker, Cringle, Sinderland and Poynton Brooks and their tributaries.

River levels are expected to fall this morning before rising again this afternoon, overnight and into tomorrow morning, 03/01/2024.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

This message will be updated as the situation changes or by 10:00 on 03/01/2024.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Tuesday 2nd January 2024. The Rivers Deben and Lark have risen in response to the overnight rainfall. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for further rain during the day. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Wednesday 3rd January, or as the situation changes.

The River Lavant is higher than normal following a wet autumn and 20mm of rain Monday. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Tuesday morning. Minor flood impacts could continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens. In East Lavant water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green, and access bridges across the river. The river will be high at The Sadlers in Westhampnett. Flooding is not expected in Chichester City Centre. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00 02/01/2024. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 02/01/2024 but will be higher than normal all week. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024. On Thursday, river levels could end up similar to mid December 2023. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to operate the River Lavant Flood Alleviation scheme to reduce the flood risk on the River Lavant. We will update this message by 22:00 on 02/01/2024.

River levels continue to rise at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continues over the next few days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. 

Predicted peaks:- Mythe 4.2m to 4.5m overnight Wednesday, 03/01/2024, 
Haw Bridge 5.1m to 5.4m overnight Thursday, 04/01/2024.
Sandhurst 3.9m to 4.2m this afternoon, 02/01/2024, 
Gloucester 3.5m to 3.9m this afternoon, 02/01/2024. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 7pm today, 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock and Kegworth river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby Road, the B5328 Cossington Road and the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes.
Areas also at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Loughborough, Zouch, Kegworth, Ratcliffe on Soar to Redhill Marina, the A6006 at Zouch, Soar Lane Sutton Bonnington, Moor Lane Normanton, Station Road at Kegworth, Kegworth Road and The Green Ratcliffe on Soar.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels on the Upper River Aire are expected to fall through this morning Tuesday 2nd January 2024 but remain elevated following the recent rainfall. Standing water remains in several locations next to watercourses between Gargrave and Stockbridge, with low-lying land most affected. Please avoid using footpaths next to areas of flooded land and fast flowing water and use alternative routes for walking. Further rain is expected over the coming days, so we will continue to monitor the situation. We do not currently expect to issue any flood warnings. This message will be updated by 08:30 pm 02/01/2024 or as the situation changes.

Flooding is expected to continue at low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Lake levels remain high at the Lodore gauge throughout today, 2/1/2024. Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout this afternoon and this evening, which will fall onto saturated ground. We will continue to monitor rainfall, river, and lake levels closely. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 3/1/2024, or as the situation changes.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout this afternoon and this evening, which will fall onto saturated ground.

We will continue to monitor rainfall, river and lake levels closely. Keswick Campsite flood warning has been issued and remains in force. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 3/1/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Severn as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads & farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Gravel Hill Lane Shrewsbury, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge, Bridgnorth, property access on riverside Bridgnorth, floodplains at Hayes Basin & Leighton. 
Predicted peaks: Crew Green 6.3m to 6.6m Wednesday afternoon, 03/01/24 
Montford 6.1m to 6.5m Wednesday night, 03/01/24, 
Welshbridge 3.8m to 4.5m Thursday morning, 04/01/24, 
Buildwas 5.2m to 5.9m Thursday afternoon, 04/01/24,
Bridgnorth 4.5m to 4.8m Thursday afternoon, 04/01/24. 
Further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with Local Authorities. Please avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 03/01/24, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.60m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.96m and rising. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road above 6.18m. For up-to-date water levels visit check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/station/3064.
The weather is forecast to remain unsettled over the next few days with heavier rain on 04/01/2024.
We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely, and our staff are checking flood defences and pumps. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor stations, and will operate the pumps at Currymoor when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.
Consider weather conditions, local water levels, and any flood plans. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water. Please refer to the local authority’s @TravelSomerset for local road closures.
This message will be updated by 2pm on 03/01/24; earlier if the situation significantly changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Following the heavy rainfall since the New Year, where we have seen two inches of rain in 48 hours at many locations, borehole levels across Cranborne Chase have started to rise once more. The next three days will bring some fairly unsettled weather which could produce some heavy periods of rainfall. Groundwater levels will respond very quickly under the current very wet surface conditions. 
Ensure that any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers are in good conditions and replace any stocks of sandbags.
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can damage nearby properties. 
Environment Agency staff will monitor levels daily and this message will be updated on Thursday 4th January or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
 
Further rainfall is forecast and we expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
 
This message will be updated by 6pm today, Tuesday 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is high following 25mm of rain Monday. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Tuesday morning. The Western Rother is expected to rise higher. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens in Liss, Sheet, Iping, Stedham, Midhurst, at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. From 14:00 02/01/2024 flooding could approach properties in Iping. From 17:00 02/01/2024 flooding could approach properties at Lodsbridge near Selham and also at Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. Properties on the Lod could also be affected, including near Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane and at Halfway Bridge. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00 02/01/2024. The river will begin to fall by 02:00 03/01/2024 in Iping, but not until Thursday in Fittleworth. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024. Flood impacts could remain all week near Fittleworth. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 03/01/2024

The river should begin to fall by 15:00 02/01/2024 in Barnham, but not until Wednesday in Bersted. River levels will be higher than normal all week. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024, which will increase flood risk again. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 03/01/2024

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Tuesday 2nd January 2024 and over the next few days. High water levels are expected to continue. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Water levels also remain high around Wayford Bridge and Hoveton Broad. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Wednesday 3rd January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Following the heavy rainfall since the New Year, where we have seen two inches of rain in 48 hours at many locations, borehole levels across the West of Dorset have started to rise once more. The next three days will bring some fairly unsettled weather which could produce some heavy periods of rainfall. Groundwater levels will respond very quickly under the current very wet surface conditions. 
Ensure that any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers are in good conditions and replace any stocks of sandbags.
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can damage nearby properties. 
Environment Agency staff will monitor levels daily and this message will be updated on Thursday 4th January or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Piddle following the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from groundwater levels.  There are further showers and very strong winds forecast today and tomorrow.  Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further at the Willington and Shardlow gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to increase over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 24 hours 21mm of rain has fallen at Wroxall. This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall already experienced over the last few months. From around 13:00 today (02/01/2024) water will be ponded on low lying land adjacent to the river throughout the river valley and on roads, cycle tracks and footpaths. At Langbridge and Alverstone Road Bridge, the river will be close to the top of the riverbank. Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road, Sandown may occur from 18:00 today. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Further rain is possible today, up to 15mm. Property flooding is possible should this rain materialise. Bembridge sluice is operating normally. We continue to monitor and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 15:00 on 03/01/2024, or sooner if we expect property flooding.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels are slowly rising in response to recent rainfall across the area and have continued rising at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Upper Og Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level is 8.92 m at Huish Episcopi pumping station. The drain level is 8.06m and rising.
From Muchelney, flooding will affect the road to Langport if water levels exceed 7.30m, to Long Load above 7.86m, to Thorney above 7.93m and to Drayton above 8.80m. Property flooding is expected above 8.35m.
The weather is forecast to remain unsettled over the next few days with showers and heavier rain on 04/01/2024. 
We are currently unable to pump at stations upstream of Langport; but we will operate the pumps at Huish Episcopi and others as soon as river levels reduce. The downstream Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate water.
We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels, and our staff are checking flood defences and pumps.
Please refer to check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels for the latest.
Consider local water levels, weather conditions and any flood plans. Do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closures.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 2am tomorrow 3rd January 2024, and from midnight on the 4th January 2024. High water levels are expected to continue. This is due to the current weather conditions and the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Wednesday 3rd January, or as the situation changes.

In Hambledon, groundwater levels are very high, but have just started to slowly fall following a week of mostly dry weather. Since Friday 22/12/2023, the level at Whitedale Farm has fallen by 50cm. Cellar flooding is affecting a number of properties on West and East Street. Groundwater is inundating the sewerage system and water is pushing up through manhole covers. Fareham Road is flooded, and the football pitch is being affected by a mixture of groundwater and sewerage. From today (27/12/2023) until Sunday 31/12/2023, the weather is forecast to be unsettled with up to 35mm of rain forecast across this period. Groundwater levels are expected to continue slowly falling during that time but if heavy rain affects Hambledon, groundwater levels could rise again and more properties could be affected by cellar flooding in early January 2024. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and continue to monitor the situation. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 03/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high but are now very slowly falling following a week of mostly dry weather. Since Friday 22/12/2023, the groundwater level at Finchdean has fallen by 9cm. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are both flowing. Water is affecting the ford in Rowlands Castle and minor flooding impacts are affecting roads in the area. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. From today (27/12/2023) until Sunday 31/12/2023, the weather is forecast to be unsettled with up to 35mm of rain forecast in that period. Groundwater levels are expected to continue slowly falling during that time. Further road and cellar flooding is possible after the next heavy rainfall event. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remain prepared for further flooding impacts this winter. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 03/01/2024.

items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have dropped on the Dorcan Brook and top of the River Cole. Levels remain high but are dropping slowly on the lower reaches of the River Cole. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 2/1/24, especially in the Inglesham area. 

Further rainfall is forecast through this morning, 2/1/24, which may be heavy at times, with showers through the afternoon. Unsettled conditions will persist for the remainder of the week. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. River levels may rise again in response to the forecast rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 2/1/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Heavy rain falling in the area over the last 24 hours has caused the River Axe to rise. River levels are starting to decrease in the upper catchment, but we expect them to remain higher than normal due to further showers which are forecast through to the weekend.
Property flooding is expected at Chard Junction, Axe Farm, Coaxdon and Weycroft Cottages, Mosterton, Clapton, Tytherleigh and Broom, A358 crossing at Weycroft, B3165 Clapton, A3066 Mosterton, Axminster (Stoneybridge). Flooding to riverside property and highways at the B3165 at Mosterton and Clapton is expected imminently. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas.
People in this area should consider taking action now and install any property flood resilience measures. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the night, and this message will be updated by 10:00am on Wednesday 3/1/24, or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are rising following the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of low lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are around Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukeley and Brampton. Further heavy rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours which will see river levels continue to rise. You are advised to move cars out of these flood risk areas. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, avoid walking or driving through flood water and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 02/01/24.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 15mm of rain has been recorded in Romsey. This total, whilst not that large, has added to a river which is already high as a result of heavy rainfall over the last few weeks. From 10:00 (02/01/2024), the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the mill building at East Wellow. In the next 8 hours, further heavy rain is forecast with up to 15mm possible. Given the amount of rain currently affecting the area, by 18:00 it is possible that a Flood Warning will be issued for onset of isolated property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 15:00 on 03/01/2024 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high following 15mm of rain Monday. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Tuesday morning. Rivers will rise higher. In addition to flooding affecting fields, rural roads and Crowhurst Recreation Ground, from 11:30 02/01/2024 flooding could approach a small number of riverside properties in Crowhurst. On Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. From 12:00 02/01/2024 flood water will also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00 02/01/2024. The river should begin to fall by 19:00 02/01/2024 in Crowhurst, but not until Wednesday in Bulverhythe. The river could be higher than normal all week and with another 20-30mm of rain possible Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024, flood risk could increase again. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 02/01/2024

Flooding will continue to affect fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield and from 15:00 on Tuesday 02/01/2023, water might approach isolated farm buildings and property at Slaughter Bridge on the Coolham Road. It is possible water may approach gardens of properties at Church Close, Shipley. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00. The river should begin to fall by 23:00 on 02/01/2024, but could be higher than normal all week. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast on Thursday afternoon (04/01/2024), which will increase flood risk again. Some roads, including the Coolham Road at Slaughter Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 03/01/2024.

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Egginton River gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past 24 hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected throughout today 02/01/24 and overnight. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Foston Brook, Hilton Brook and Egginton Brook.   

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to continue to rise throughout today and remain high overnight and into tomorrow morning 03/01/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message: Flooding is possible from this evening, Monday 01/01/24 and overnight into Tuesday. Over the last week we have seen heavy rain fall across Devon, and further spells of rain, which may be heavy in places are expected on Monday evening and overnight. This means that river levels in the South Devon Rivers area will rise, and will remain high for the next couple of days, as heavy rain is falling on already wet catchments. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. More heavy rain accompanied by very windy conditions on Tuesday will cause river levels to rise again. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by the afternoon on Tuesday 02/01/24, or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high at the Wingfield Park river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads along the River Amber around Ambergate.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 03/01/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Cheswick Green gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible tonight, 02/01/24.     
We expect river levels to rise until early tomorrow morning on 02/01/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning on 03/01/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising following the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Tove between Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook and the Stoke Bruerne Marina. Move cars out of this flood risk area. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Further heavy rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours which will see river levels continue to rise. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and avoid walking or driving through flood water. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 02/01/24.

The River Ouse is high following 20mm of rain Monday, and expected to rise higher. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Tuesday morning. Rivers will rise higher. Flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens and rural roads, including at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. From 13:00 02/01/2024 flooding could approach properties near Freshfield Mill Farm, Freshmill and Millers Cottages on Sloop Lane. From 12:00 02/01/2024 flooding could affect the Anchor Inn, and approach properties in Barcombe Mills from 19:00 02/01/2023. Barcombe Mills road could be impassable. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00 02/01/2024. However, the river will not begin to fall until Wednesday, and will be higher than normal all week. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024, which could again cause flooding. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 13:00 03/01/2024

items.message: River levels remain high on the Congresbury Yeo due to rainfall overnight. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Congresbury Yeo, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around roads at Wrington and Iwood. No property flooding is expected. The weather is forecast to remain unsettled over the next few days with showers and heavier rain on 04/01/2024. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00am tomorrow, 03/01/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Nottingham Woodborough river gauge as a result of further heavy rainfall on Tuesday. Consequently, flooding could occur imminently. Areas most at risk are Woodborough including Main Street which is likely to be impassable, affecting access in and out of the village. Flooding may also affect properties on Lingwood Lane, Smalls Croft and Westfield Lane. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  This message will be updated by 21:00 this evening, 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

River levels are rising at the Lowdham Grange river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to occur from 5pm into this evening, 02/01/2024. Areas most at risk are Lowdham Main Street, and Station Road, including Merevale, and Limetree Gardens.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels are likely to remain high overnight into Wednesday, 03/01/2024 and then begin to fall.

items.description: Clay Coton Brook at Clay Coton and Yelvertoft Brook at Yelvertoft
items.message:
River levels are rising slowly at the Clay Coton gauge as a result of the heavy rainfall today.  Consequently, the flooding of roads and property is possible later today (02/01/2024).  Flooding is affecting properties in Cold Ashby Road in Clay Coton and Yelvertoft Village, including High Street, Swinnertons Lane, Elkins Close, Elkington Road, Bridgend and Ashwells Lane and along Lilbourne Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon, but is forecast to begin clearing from approximately 21:00.  We expect river levels to remain high overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning (03/01/24), or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast today so we expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or external garages is possible close to the river.  We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. This message will be updated as the situation changes. Please call Floodline on 0345 988 1188 to check if this Flood Alert has been removed or look online www.gov.uk/flood

items.message:
A flood alert has been issued. River levels are rising on the Bristol Avon, Broadmead Brook, River Boyd due to rainfall. 

Areas most at risk include low lying land at Hanham Lock and the floodplain upstream of Bath with further showers forecast throughout the evening. Further rainfall is expected this afternoon and overnight.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will continue to monitor closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Further rainfall is forecast through this morning, 2/1/24, which may be heavy at times, with showers through the afternoon. Unsettled conditions will persist for the remainder of the week. River levels are expected to continue to rise over the next 48 hours in response to rainfall and will remain high over the coming days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 2/1/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 35mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech. From 14:00 on 02/01/2024, flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00, with a mostly dry day on Wednesday (03/01/2024). The river should begin to fall by 04:00 (03/01/2024). However, with another 15-30mm of rain possible on Thursday (04/01/2024), flood risk could return. Land will remain flooded over the next few days. Generally, water levels will remain higher than normal and the river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the next few weeks. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 on 02/01/2024.

Water levels in the River Rother between Renishaw and Rotherham are now starting to fall after last night's rainfall. Further rain today (2nd January) will cause the river to rise again from around 15:00. 
 Areas affected by the rising water will principally be lower lying areas of farm and park land next to the Rother. Please take care near waterlogged land and flooded fields and use alternative routes until the water has receded.
This message will be updated by 08:50 pm 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are high and continue to rise on the Middle Dorset Stour and River Iwerne after the recent rainfall. We are monitoring the rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have, and start acting on your flood plan if you have one.  Residents are strongly urged to take action now.  Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. This message will be updated by 4:00pm on 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but stable on much of the River Ock as a result of recent rainfall, with levels rising steadily in the Abingdon area. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 2/1/24, especially in the Charney Bassett and  Abingdon areas. Further rainfall is forecast through this morning, 2/1/24, which may be heavy at times, with showers through the afternoon. Unsettled conditions will persist for the remainder of the week. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 2/1/24, or as the situation changes.

Over the last few days and overnight we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Till area. This means that the River Till is rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from early this morning, Tuesday 2nd January, onwards. Further rainfall is forecast today so we expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. items.message: River levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 15:30 on 02/01/24. The causeway at Sutton Gault currently has 35cm water on the road. The causeway at Welney currently has 10cm of water on the road. The causeway at Earith currently has no water on the road. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Further rainfall is expected in the next 24hrs. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 2:00 PM on 02/01/2024, with total water level of 1.33 mAOD with a Force 7 Westerly wind forecast.  Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.  Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be closing flood gates if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, close to the surface and rising at the East Dean borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water could also affect the B2141 Chilgrove road. Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday should see very little rainfall, but another 20-30mm of rain could occur Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024. Groundwater at all boreholes could rise a small amount through to next week 08/01/2024. Flood impacts are expected to remain until the middle of January, and potentially longer, or affecting more people if wet weather continues. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 06/01/2024

The water level in the River Lymington at Brockenhurst is high and rising. In the last 24 hours 19mm has been recorded at Brockenhurst. From 11:00 (02/01/2024) the river will be much higher than normal and drainage ditches through the New Forest will be flooding land and roads. It will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 10 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. Given the persistent nature of the rainfall which will affect the area, we may issue a Flood Warning at Brockenhurst, for onset of property flooding from the river. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Watersplashes will deepen over the next 24 hours. Do not drive through floodwater. Properties located nearest to the river should take appropriate action to ensure they can protect property. This Flood Alert will be updated at 15:00 on 03/01/2024, or sooner if we think property flooding will occur.
River levels are now returning to normal.
This alert has been removed due to levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

The River Ems is higher than normal following a wet autumn and 15mm of rain on Monday. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Tuesday morning. Minor flood impacts could continue to affect fields, Brook Meadows and rural roads. Small amounts of water could also affect gardens of properties on North Street, River Street and at the Wren Centre, Westbourne, and also near Lumley Mill and Victoria Terrace, Emsworth. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00 on 02/01/2024. The river should peak by 15:00 Tuesday 02/01/2024, but will be higher than normal all week. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024, which will again cause the river to rise. On Thursday, river levels could peak higher than they were throughout 2023. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Westbourne and Emsworth, if you have them. Flooding may occur in a short space of time, so please be prepared. We are operating our structure at Constant Springs and clearing grilles to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 on 02/01/2024.

This message will be updated by 6pm on Tuesday 2 January, or sooner if the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Woodridings Stream and River Pinn due to heavy rainfall last night, Monday 1 January and through to this morning, Tuesday 2 January.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Woodridings Stream and River Pinn, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Woodhall Gate, Albury Drive, Murray Crescent, Grange Gardens, Chapel Lane, Marsh Road, Hatch End and High Road. The river is expected to peak at 4pm today, Tuesday 2 January.

Light rainfall is forecast tomorrow, Wednesday 3 January, so river levels are expected to begin to fall from this afternoon.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 6pm this evening, Tuesday 2 January or as the situation changes.

The water level in the lower River Meon at Titchfield is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 15mm of rain has been recorded at Peel Common. Today (Tuesday 02/01/2024) out of bank flooding will impact fields at Titchfield Hill, with high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and the Tanneries Industrial Estate. While groundwater and river levels are currently so high, any intense rainfall events are now likely to cause surface water flooding in Titchfield High Street. Further rain is forecast for this morning and Thursday. The river may continue to rise until 23:00 this evening. Low lying land will remain flooded over the next few days. Given the rain forecast, it is possible that a Flood Warning may need to be issued for onset of property flooding from the river, mainly affecting Bridge Cottage. Our operational staff will keep the river clear of reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This Flood Alert will be updated by 15:00 on 03/01/2024, or sooner should we expect property flooding.

River levels remain high on the River Wylye at South Newton due to rainfall.  Areas most at risk include tributaries between Norton Ferris and Wilton.  There are further showers and very strong winds forecast today and tomorrow.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Tuesday 2nd January 2024. The Rivers Wid and Can have risen in response to the overnight rainfall. It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few hours. The forecast is for further rain during the day. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Wednesday 3rd January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Rattlesden River and River Gipping, through and including Stowmarket and Needham Market
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Tuesday 2nd January 2024. The River Gipping and Rattlesden River are rising steadily in response to the overnight rainfall. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for further rain during the day. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Wednesday 3rd January, or as the situation changes.

River levels are expected to remain high on the River Alt due to rainfall today.
Further flooding could occur at River Alt and other watercourses from Huyton to Hightown including, Kirkby, Fazakerley, Maghull, Formby, Aughton, Sefton and Lunt from 10:00 AM as river levels are expected to remain high as further rainfall is forecast throughout the day.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:30 PM on 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but slowly dropping, on the River Dikler following last night's rain. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 2/1/24, especially in areas close to Bourton on the Water.

Further rainfall is forecast through this morning, 2/1/24, which may be heavy at times, with showers through the afternoon. Unsettled conditions will persist for the remainder of the week. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. River levels are expected to slowly drop through this morning, but may rise again in response to the forecast rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 2/1/24, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but slowly falling, on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 2/1/24, especially in the Steventon area. Further rainfall is forecast through this morning, 2/1/24, which may be heavy at times, with showers through the afternoon. Unsettled conditions will persist for the remainder of the week. We expect river levels to slowly drop through thir morning, but may rise again in response to forecast rainfall. Levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 2/1/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels are reacting quickly, and rising sharply in response to steady rainfall from Storm Henk. Flooding is expected. Areas most at risk are around Bourn Brook, from Caxton to Comberton.   Further rainfall is expected over through today which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 03/01/2024.

River levels are reacting quickly, and rising sharply in response to rainfall from Storm Henk. Flooding is expected. Areas most at risk are around Cottenham Lode including Oakington Brook, Wash Pit Brook and Beck Brook.  Further rainfall is expected through today which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 03/01/2024.

River levels remain high at the Llanymynech and Crew Green river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect river levels to rise again as a result of recent heavy rainfall with the renewed risk of flooding to properties and roads in and around Melverley including Melverley to Melverley Green and Ponthen to Melverley roads.
Predicted peaks:- 4.3m and 4.5m is expected at Llanymynech river gauge this morning, Tuesday 02/01/24. Crew Green 6.0 to 6.4m Wednesday afternoon, 03/01/24.
Further rainfall is forecast which could push river levels higher again later in the week. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 6pm today, Tuesday 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Llanymynech river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect river levels to rise again as a result of recent heavy rainfall, with the renewed risk of flooding to properties and roads in and around Maesbrook.

Predicted peaks:- 4.3m and 4.5m is expected at Llanymynech river gauge this morning, Tuesday 02/01/24.

Further rainfall is forecast which could push river levels higher again later in the week. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated by 6pm today, Tuesday 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the Rivers Irk and Medlock, Wince and Worsley Brooks and their tributaries.

Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Wyboston to the south of Brampton, including Duloe Brook, Hen Brook and Fox Brook. River levels are expected to continue to rise, and we are likely to issue more messages for a wider area, over the next few hours. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. River levels are expected to remain high throughout today, 02/01/2024, and into tomorrow, 03/01/2024.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

This message will be updated as the situation changes or by 10:00 on 03/01/2024.

River levels are rising at the Shipston gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight and during today.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, 02/01/24.     
We expect river levels to rise until later this evening.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on Osbaldwick Beck and Tanghall Beck. Flooding remains possible at locations near Osbaldwick Beck and Tanghall Beck, with low-lying land expected to be most affected. We expect further rainfall over the coming days. Our incident room is open and we are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels closely. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:30pm on Tuesday 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Following 30mm of rain Monday and Tuesday, the Cuckmere River is high and rising. The Bull River is high, and expected to rise Tuesday evening. From 16:00 on 02/01/2024 flooding will be very close to properties on Mill Lane Hellingly, at Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and will continue to affect fields and rural roads including Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From 21:00 on 02/01/2024 flooding will also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, including gardens and properties on those roads. Very little rainfall is forecast for the rest of Tuesday and Wednesday. The river should begin to fall by 23:00 on 02/01/2024, but with another 15-30mm forecast for Thursday, property flooding could again be possible. Land will remain flooded over the next few days. The river might not return nearer to normal until Friday evening. Some roads including Mill Road and Church Road may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 03/01/2024.

River levels in the River Aire between Keighley and Castleford remain high but have started to fall across the majority of the catchment, following the response to rainfall overnight. Levels at Castleford are expected to peak later this morning Tuesday 02/01/2024 before slowly falling throughout the day. 
 
Further rain is expected over the coming days so we will continue to closely monitor the situation. We do not expect to  issue any flood warnings. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
 
This message will be updated by 08:50 pm 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high in the Lower River Aire catchment following last nights rainfall, and flooding is still possible today Tuesday 02/01/2024. Therefore this Flood Alert remains in force. Washlands between Beal and Gowdall have been steadily filling. River levels are expected to peak later this morning at Knottingley and will then fall slowly throughout the day. However, there is further rain forecast today which may see levels increasing, although at lower levels than we have seen in the last few days. Areas most at risk include River Aire from Ferrybridge to Chapel Haddlesey. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 9 pm 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Loddon as a result of a period of sustained rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 02/01/24, especially in the Sindlesham area. Further heavy rainfall is forecast in the coming days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated this evening, 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, and following Monday and Tuesday's rain is now slowly rising again at the Compton borehole. Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday should see very little rainfall, but another 20-30mm of rain could occur Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024. Minor groundwater flood impacts will likely continue or return this week, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. Particularly during or after rain. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any rainfall over winter. Colder weather, with less rain could be possible next week, which could allow groundwater to stabilise and potentially fall. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 06/01/2024

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but currently stable on the River Kennet following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 2/1/24, especially in the Theale area. Further rainfall is forecast through this morning, 2/1/24, which may be heavy at times, with showers through the afternoon. Unsettled conditions will persist for the remainder of the week. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. River levels may rise further in response to recent and forecast rainfall. Further unsettled weather is expected over the coming week. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 2/1/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high downstream of Tadcaster and at Cawood gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include the Tidal River Wharfe downstream of Tadcaster. Further rainfall is expected on Tuesday, 02/01/2024. Our incident response staff have closed flood gates and checked defences in the area. We are managing pumping in the area and the flood warning at Ryther remains in force. Our incident room is open and we continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid roads between Tadcaster and Cawood that are affected by flooding. This message will be updated by 5:30pm on Tuesday 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Whilst this flood warning remains in force, the local authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be in place and further updates will be available through the local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.message:

Flooding is forecast to affect locations, near the Colne; Frays; Wraysbury and Poyle Channel, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Longford and Staines Moor.

Over half a month's rain has fallen in January 2024 already. The River Arun is high and rising. From 06:00 on 03/01/2024 flooding could affect the A29 at Pulborough. Water will be extensive through fields and could affect gardens and approach properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. After each high tide, water will be close to the tops of the banks and in fields near Houghton Bridge, Amberley. With tides low and falling, flood water is only expected to affect fields in Arundel. Almost no rain is forecast Tuesday evening and Wednesday, but another 20-30mm of rain is possible Thursday 04/01/2024. In Pulborough the river will continue rising until at least Friday, so property flooding could be possible in Pulborough Wednesday afternoon. River levels could rise as high as November 2023. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 13:00 on 03/01/2024.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are slowly rising on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 2/1/24, especially in the areas closest to the river between Shillingford and Pangbourne. Further rainfall is forecast through this morning, 2/1/24, which may be heavy at times, with showers through the afternoon. Unsettled conditions will persist for the remainder of the week. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly over the next 48 hours. Further unsettled weather is expected over the coming week. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 2/1/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise steadily on the River Bourne at Tidworth Manor Bridge and Salisbury Bourne river gauges due to rainfall.  Areas most at risk include tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.  There are further showers and very strong winds forecast today and tomorrow.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 03/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover are high and continue to slowly rise. Groundwater is affecting cellars in Appleshaw and Hatherden, the sewer network in Penton Mewsey, and the main road in Penton Grafton. The spring at Biddesden could begin to flow from Thursday (28/12/2023). From today (27/12/2023) until Sunday (31/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be unsettled with up to 35mm across these five days. We expect groundwater levels to peak around the time of New Year. From the beginning of January 2024, cellar flooding in Penton Grafton and Kimpton, groundwater emergence into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton, and surface water flooding in Thruxton could be possible, and is also likely after further heavy rain affects the area. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove valuables from cellars and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 03/01/2024.

In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and have risen by 30cm in the last 4 days. Ongoing cellar flooding impacts will be occurring in the south end of the village and at the Dolphin Inn pub. Groundwater will be impacting the sewerage network. From today (27/12/2023) until Sunday (31/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be unsettled with up to 35mm of rain forecast across the five days. Groundwater levels in Hursley are expected to peak before the New Year. From today (27/12/2023), it is possible that most cellars in the village will begin to be impacted by groundwater. If heavy rain affects Hursley, then groundwater levels could continue to rise and cellar flooding will become deeper. We continue to monitor the forecast and groundwater levels. Please remove valuables from cellars, and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 03/01/2024.

River levels are falling at the Titley Mill river gauge. However, they are expected to rise again as a result of heavy rainfall. 

Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.

Further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 6pm today, Tuesday 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

The River Arun is high and rising. 25mm of rain has been recorded at Itchingfield on Monday and Tuesday. From 20:00 on 02/01/2024 minor flooding could affect grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court, and possibly fields behind Arunside and the playground of Arunside School in Horsham. Tuesday afternoon, flooding will affect fields, gardens and rural roads between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay, with water approaching isolated mill properties from 22:00 on 02/01/2024. Only isolated showers are forecast Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday should be mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 04:00 on 03/01/2024 in Horsham, but with another 15-30mm of rain possible Thursday, flood risk could return. Land will remain flooded over the next few days. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 12:00 on 03/01/2024.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today 02/01/24, especially in the Shiplake area. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the coming days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated this evening, 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

The River Lox is high following 20mm of rain Monday. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Tuesday morning. Rivers will rise higher. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the length of the river Lox, including isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold, and riverside properties on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. From 18:00 on 02/01/2024, water could approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. River levels could end up as high as November 2023. Tuesday's rain should ease by 13:00 on 02/01/2024. The river should begin to fall by 09:00 on 03/01/2024, but will be higher than normal all week. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 04/01/2024, which will increase flood risk again. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 03/01/2024.

River levels remain high at the Ross-On-Wye River gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. 
Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 4.1m to 4.6m this evening, 02/01/2024. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours which could push river levels higher again later in the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 6pm today, 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Bourne from Hadlow to East Peckham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen on the River Bourne due to heavy rainfall throughout last night and this morning. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Hadlow and Little Mill. Further rainfall is forecast throughout today with further showers forecast later this week. River levels are expected to remain high into Wednesday, 03/01/2024. 

Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 20:00 PM on 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. However, river levels remain high due to recent rainfall, and will remain responsive to further rainfall with the already saturated ground conditions. Further rainfall is forecast today, 02/01/24 and in the coming days. Therefore, flooding of low lying land remains a risk in the area over the coming days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated by this evening, 02/01/24, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Medway due to heavy rainfall in recent days. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Tonbridge playing fields and town centre car parks, through to Tudeley, East Peckham and Yalding. This is likely to include the sports pitches, also known as the racecourse, in Tonbridge and Postern Lane. Minor flooding within the Little Venice park at Yalding is possible from Tuesday afternoon. Initial flood peaks are expected in the early hours of Wednesday morning. There will be a drier spell over Wednesday 3/1/24, but with further rainfall expected on Thursday 4/1/24. River levels are expected to remain high into Friday, 5/1/2024. 

Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn
items.message: River levels are rising at the Saxons Lode river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect property at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn. Hanley Road Closes. Predicted peak:- Saxons Lode 5.1m to 5.4m Thursday morning 04/01/2024. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm today, 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high and continue to slowly fall after another week of mostly dry weather. The Winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for most of December, and there may still be some residual water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. From today (27/12/2023) until Sunday 31/12/2023, the weather is forecast to be unsettled with up to 35mm of rain forecast in that time. However, groundwater levels are expected to continue falling during that time. If very heavy rain affects the Meon Valley, groundwater levels will begin to rise again. Cellar flooding caused by groundwater remains a possibility this winter. Please remain prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please check that they can operate effectively. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 03/01/2024.

items.description: River Severn at Chaceley and Haw Bridge
items.message:
River levels are continuing to rise at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Chaceley and Haw Bridge, including the B4213. 

Predicted peak at Haw Bridge 5.2m to 5.4m Thursday morning 04/01/24. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 7pm today, 02/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
